Launch Archive

Recent Attempts

Launch 47 • Last Thursday
"The Audacity"
Promising first 8 seconds. Then the starboard vacuum tube array overheated and the craft performed what we're calling an "unplanned lateral excursion" into Mrs. Pemberton's greenhouse. She's invoicing us for the orchids.
Peak: 89 ft | Duration: 11s | Orchids destroyed: 14
Launch 44 • 12 Jan
"Evelyn's Folly II"
The craft achieved vertical lift but the nosecone detached at 200ft and embedded itself in the Little Piddling village sign. The body continued upward for another 142ft. We're counting this as two separate records.
Peak: 342 ft (combined) | Status: Partial success
Launch 41 • 28 Dec
"New Year's Resolution"
Did not launch. Kevin had wired the ignition to the coffee machine. We discovered this when Sandra pressed the brew button and the launchpad caught fire. The coffee was fine.
Peak: 0 ft | Coffee quality: Excellent
Launch 38 • 15 Nov
"The Dignified Retreat"
Launched successfully but the guidance system, sourced from a 1994 TomTom, directed the rocket toward Birmingham. We lost contact at 310ft. If you're in the West Midlands area and find a chrome cylinder with "PN" painted on it, that's ours.
Peak: 310 ft | Current location: Unknown

Visitor Reviews

Haiku Only, Please

Per Evelyn's directive, all reviews of Project Nightingale launches must be submitted in haiku form. "If you can't express it in seventeen syllables, you haven't suffered enough." — E.P.

Engine sputtered out
Dreams of space now just debris
Back to the drawing
— Gerald T., Season Pass Holder

Launchpad Lounge

24/7 Live Jazz

Now Playing • Hour 10,247
"Ballad for a Falling Object (Reprise)"

The Apogee Three have been performing continuously in the Launchpad Lounge since October 2023. They are contractually obligated to play until we reach orbit. Morale varies.

Upright Bass
Desmond Fairweather
Former London Philharmonic. Lost a bet to Evelyn in 2022. Has not slept since March. His bass notes have begun to sound like weeping.
Piano
Yuki Tanaka-Smythe
Classically trained, emotionally devastated. Composes one new piece per failed launch. Her catalogue now exceeds 47 works, all in minor keys.
Trumpet (Muted)
Clarence "Biscuit" Holloway
Age 74. Says he's "seen worse gigs." Won't elaborate. The mute on his trumpet has not been removed since Launch 12. Nobody's asked why.

Official Statement

RE: AetherCorp

Let me be perfectly clear about AetherCorp and their gleaming, soulless, obscenely well-funded excuse for a space programme.

They have $4.2 billion. We have a weather balloon, three vacuum tubes from a 1962 Philips radiogram, and Desmond's bass, which I'm fairly certain has achieved sentience.

They have 300 aerospace engineers. We have Kevin. Kevin once wired our ignition system to the coffee machine. But Kevin has heart. Kevin cried during Launch 31 — not because it exploded, but because it was "the most beautiful thing he'd ever seen." That is what AetherCorp will never have.

Their CEO, Maximilian Stroud-Whitley, called our programme "charmingly quaint" on Radio 4. Charmingly quaint. I have been to space, Maximilian. Briefly. Emotionally. And I will get there physically if it takes every last penny of my inheritance and every orchid in Mrs. Pemberton's greenhouse.

— Evelyn Periwinkle, Director
Museum of Magnificent Mistakes, Space Division
Written at 3:47 AM, two gins in
